channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [JENA-1719] Fuseki with TDB2 using RDFS inference throws exception on queries
item.description:

Steps to reproduce (see attachments for files)

 

1. Generate a tdb2 database from the toy data

$tdb2.tdbloader --loc=graph data.nt

2. Start fuseki-server with the attached config (adjust path to ontology file in the config accordingly)

$fuseki-server --config=example.ttl

3. Issue a small query

$s-query --server=http://localhost:3030/example "select * where {?s a <http://example.com/ns/Person>} limit 10"

4. Issue another query

$s-query --server=http://localhost:3030/example "select * where {?s a <http://example.com/ns/Person>} limit 1000"

At this point, I consistently get this response:

Error 500: Iterator used inside a different transaction
500: http://localhost:3030/example?query=select+%2A+where+%7B%3Fs+a+%3Chttp%3A%2F%2Fexample.com%2Fns%2FPerson%3E%7D+limit+1000

And on the server log see the above stack trace.  I have encountered this in both the 3.11 and 3.10 releases.  I have not tried on earlier versions.
item.summary: Fuseki with TDB2 using RDFS inference throws exception on queries

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
This does not look like JENA-1492.

What is happening is that partial inference work in the first query is being carried over into the second query but the TDB2 iterator/transaction tracker caches this. The first query inference work is partial because of the LIMIT but work up to the limit looks to be cached so a that goes beyond the limit of the first is affected where as same limit is not.

Commit ddbaeaa0653fa0b60da500b8d14cfa6ea8cefe02 in jena's branch refs/heads/JENA-1719 from der
[ https://gitbox.apache.org/repos/asf?p=jena.git;h=ddbaeaa ]

JENA-1719: Work around for iterators being held across transactions

Was able to reduce this to a simpler test case which doesn't require fuseki or the full RDFS rule set and find a workaround.

Test case and workaround are in https://github.com/apache/jena/pull/580 - as it says there this doesn't fix the deeper underlying problem but does at least work around it. The testcase in the PR avoids using tdb2 so that it can be included as a reasoner test in jena-core but a separate "integration" test (not in the PR) which more closely matches the original report and uses tdb2 does pass with this PR applied.
